project: LLM Rewrite Test Suite — ReqRight AI

requirements.text: The system should handle data properly and efficiently.
requirements.rationale: TC-2.7: Tests vague terms, missing entity, wrong obligation keyword.

requirements.text: All errors must be handled in a timely manner where possible.
requirements.rationale: TC-2.8: Tests absolutes, escape clause, wrong keyword, vague timing.

requirements.text: Data shall be processed by the system within 5 seconds.
requirements.rationale: TC-2.9: Tests passive voice, missing tolerance.

requirements.text: The system shall always be available and reliable.
requirements.rationale: TC: Tests absolute (always), multiple thoughts (and), vague (reliable).

requirements.text: It shall send notifications to users.
requirements.rationale: TC: Tests pronoun (It), missing named entity.

requirements.text: The system shall be able to process approx 1000 requests.
requirements.rationale: TC: Tests superfluous infinitive (be able to), abbreviation (approx), missing tolerance.

requirements.text: The SW shall handle errors, exceptions, and edge cases as needed.
requirements.rationale: TC: Tests escape clause (as needed), multiple thoughts, abbreviation (SW).

requirements.text: Performance should be adequate for the intended use case.
requirements.rationale: TC: Tests wrong keyword (should), vague (adequate), not measurable.

requirements.text: The Authentication_Module shall verify each user credential within 2 ± 0.5 seconds of submission.
The Logging_Service shall record each system event with timestamp, severity level, and source module identifier.

decisions.title: Use Claude Sonnet 4.5 for LLM rewrites
decisions.desc: Selected Claude Sonnet 4.5 as the default model for requirement rewriting due to balance of quality and cost.
decisions.rationale: Sonnet provides strong reasoning at $3/M input tokens. Haiku available as cheaper fallback.

risks.title: LLM hallucination changes requirement intent
risks.desc: The LLM may introduce scope or meaning not present in the original requirement.
risks.mitigation: Review panel shows original vs suggested side-by-side. User must explicitly accept.

risks.title: API cost exceeds budget during batch operations
risks.desc: Batch rewriting large requirement sets could consume significant API credits.
risks.mitigation: Cost estimate shown in settings. Batch processes sequentially so user can monitor.

stakeholders.name: QA Tester
stakeholders.concerns: Test coverage, reproducible results, clear pass/fail criteria
stakeholders.expectations: Loadable test data with known-bad requirements for each INCOSE rule category

useCases.name: Single LLM Rewrite Test
useCases.trigger: Tester selects bad requirement and clicks ✨ LLM Rewrite
useCases.preconditions: API key configured and connected, test project loaded
useCases.mainFlow:
1. Select REQ-001 through REQ-008 one at a time
2. Click ✨ LLM Rewrite
3. Review panel appears with original vs suggested
4. Check score improvement
5. Accept or discard
6. Verify version history entry
useCases.postconditions: Requirement rewritten with higher INCOSE score

useCases.name: Batch LLM Rewrite Test
useCases.trigger: Tester clicks ✨ LLM Fix All Below 80%
useCases.preconditions: API key configured, test project loaded with mix of good and bad requirements
useCases.mainFlow:
1. Open ⚡ AI modal
2. Click ✨ LLM Fix All Below 80%
3. Watch progress bar
4. Verify only REQ-001 to REQ-008 are processed
5. REQ-009 and REQ-010 should be skipped (score > 80%)
6. Check results list for score changes
7. Dismiss progress panel
8. Verify all rewrites in version history
useCases.postconditions: All low-scoring requirements improved, high-scoring untouched
